titleStmt.title: 1843 February 20: Octavius Hadfield to Mrs. John Mason

sourceDesc.p: Wellington City Libraries book of typed transcriptions. Spine title "Hadfield, Typescript (amended) letters 1833-1854". Corrected by Gillian Ryan 1960. Page 92. "Extracts of letters from Octavius to Mrs. Mason." Unspecified source of extract, time of extracting, person who extracted and nature or extent of excluded material - enquiry emailed to Frith Driver-Burgess at Wellington City Libraries on 27.11.15 regarding this. These extracts are all from letters written within the first months following Rev. John Mason's death, which Octavius Hadfield witnessed and described in his letter to the C.M.S., reproduced in their obituary, available at http://www.enzb.auckland.ac.nz/document?wid=4078&page=1&action=null
Re-typed and encoded into TEI by Melissa Bryant, 27.11.15

front.p: 1843 February 20: Octavius Hadfield to Mrs. John Mason

body.p: The natives are in a great hurry to go away this morning; and I have therefore scarcely time to write. I have received all your letters and forwarded those for the post- - - - - - I am glad you gave some books to the Natives to whom you allude, He was just getting into his canoe, and I had none prepared; but I thought he would find Weimiar , who would have explained. -------- Mr St Hill has been staying with me a few days, making selections of land, for native reserves. He has just left me. - He says that there are no grave stones at Wellington.-------I am writing in to hurried a way to speak deliberately of yourself, but I have a hope that you may, having been brought by the Lord to this land, be directed to some work here for the Lord, I have no particular thing in my mind, but I think with your views of what Christ has done for you, you would be delighted in spending yourself for the welfare of His people who are His body and consequently are with Himself-and we know from His own words that what is done for His people he considers as done for Himself. May the Lord direct you- John Williams has been very long ill. I did not think he would recover------- a large blister and medicines seem to have benefited him,- I wished for him to remain but he wants to go. - Many thanks for the Greek Test- which I highly value I assure you.--ever yours faithfully in the Lord-
